facts.text: Profession tax imposed on every company and person transacting business within limits for not less than certain period.

anchor.surface_text: imposed a profession tax upon every companypany and every person who, among other things, transacts business within the limits of the municipality for number less than a certain period during a year.

facts.text: Rule 16 sets slabs of half-yearly income, first class exceeds Rs. 21,000 pays Rs. 275 per half-year.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 16 sets out slabs of half-yearly income for the purpose of assessment of companypanies and persons to the LlSup./65---12 tax. In this rule the assesees are divided into 12 classes. In the first class companye assessees whose half-yearly income exceeds Rs. 21,000 who have to pay a tax of Rs. 275 per half-year.

facts.text: Proviso to sub-r.1 r.16: company with half-yearly income >21,000 pays additional tax at 1 rupee per 100 rupees or part thereof over Rs.275.

anchor.surface_text: Then there is a proviso to sub-r.  1  which runs thus Provided that a companypany whose half-yearly income is more than twenty-one thousand rupees shall, numberwithstanding anything companytained in this or any other rule, pay in addition to the maximum half-yearly tax of rupees two hundred and seventy-five and additional half-yearly tax on such excess calculated at the rate of one rupee per one hundred rupees or part thereof.

facts.text: S.3 Indian Finance Act, 25 of 1950 repealed Travancore Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: By the operation of s. 3 of the Indian Finance Act, 25 of 1950 the Travancore Income-tax Act stood repealed and the municipal authorities companystrued the reference to the Travancore Income-tax Act in sub-r.  1  of r. 18 as reference to the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: In Harrisons and Crosfield Ltd. v. Commissioner of Quilon Municipality, Travancore-Cochin High Court held proviso obsolete.

facts.text: Notification dated February 15, 1956 amended sub-rr.1 and 2 of r.18, substituting Indian Income Tax Act 1922, deemed effective from April 1, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the appropriate authortiy amended sub-rr.  1  and  2  of r. 18 by numberification dated February 15, 1956 as follows In clause  a  of sub-rule  1  of rule 18- I.L.R. 1955 T.C. 1003. .lm15  a  for the words Travancore Income Tax Act wherever they occur, the words and figures Indian Income Tax Act, 1922 shall be substituted. ... These amendments shall be deemed to have companye into effect from 1st April 1950.

facts.text: Kerala High Court struck down s.2 of Act XIV 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court struck down this section and number the O.P. Nos. 196 to 202 of 1955 decided in October, 1956. Quilon Municipality and its Commissioner have companye up before us in appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds s.2 of Kerala Act XIV 1958 invalid violating Art.276, dismisses appeals.

anchor.surface_text: For all these reasons the amendment must, therefore, be regarded as violating the provisions of Art. 276 and we hold that the Kerala Legislature was incompetent to enact s. 2 of the Validating Act. We accordingly dismiss the appeals with companyts.

facts.text: Hypothetical figures in Ex.4,13,23 show in some periods TI2 higher than TI1 under amended proviso.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pai has sought to demonstrate by reference to actual figures that in respect of certain periods the present assessees liability to pay the tax as ascertained under the amended proviso would be higher than what it would have been under the amended proviso. facts.text: Before Constitution, Quilon Municipality tax rate exceeded Rs.250 per annum.

anchor.surface_text: Provided that if in the financial year immediately preceding the companymencement of this Constitution there was in force in the case of any State or any such municipality, board or authority a tax on professions, trades, callings or employments the rate, or the maximum rate, of which exceeded two hundred and fifty rupees per annum,
is invalid on the ground that it violates the provisions of Art. 276 of the Constitution.

concepts.interpretation: Prohibits state legislatures from validating profession taxes exceeding Rs.250 per annum post-Constitution commencement, even retrospectively, as it circumscribes legislative power with a dateline.

issues.text: whether s. 2 of the Kerala Profession Tax Validation and Reassessment Act, 1958 Act No. XIV of 1958 is invalid on the ground that it violates the provisions of Art. 276 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: s. 2 of the Kerala Profession Tax Validation and Reassessment Act, 1958 Act No. XIV of 1958 is invalid on the ground that it violates the provisions of Art. 276 of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the proviso merely purported to create a machinery for implementing the tax

anchor.surface_text: Before dealing with the effect of the amendment made to the proviso added in the year 1947 we must first consider whether the proviso merely purported to create a machinery for implementing the tax.

issues.text: whether the amended proviso was likely to enhance an assessee's liability

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, while dealing with the amendment made in the year 1956 we have to bear in mind that it was made in a provision concerning the basis of taxation. The question then would be whether the amended proviso was likely to enhance an assessee's liability.

issues.text: whether the Kerala Legislature was competent to enact s. 2 of the Validating Act purporting to validate retrospectively a profession tax exceeding Rs.250 after commencement of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: For all these reasons the amendment must, therefore, be regarded as violating the provisions of Art. 276 and we hold that the Kerala Legislature was incompetent to enact s. 2 of the Validating Act.

arguments.claim: The Validating Act merely adapts the machinery for assessment and levy of tax due to repeal of Travancore Income-tax Act and does not infringe Art. 276

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney-General who appears for the appellants contends that what the Act does is merely to adapt the machinery for the assessment and levy of the tax to a situation arising out of the repeal of the Travancore Income-Tax Act by s. 3 of the Indian Finance Act, 1950 and replacing that Act by the Indian Income-tax Act. It, therefore, according to him, does not infringe the provisions of Art. 276 of the Constitution.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to be found in three statements filed in the High Court by the respondents and marked as Ex 4, 13 and 23. The statements are identical and we would o

arguments.court_reasoning: Proviso introduces new basis for assessment by linking to income-tax profits and apportionment, affecting incidence of tax, not mere machinery

arguments.claim: Retrospectivity given to the provision does not infringe Art. 276

anchor.surface_text: He also contends that the retrospectivity given to the provision does not infringe the aforesaid constitutional provision.

arguments.court_reasoning: Art. 276 proviso circumscribes legislative power with dateline at Constitution commencement; cannot validate post-commencement excess retrospectively

arguments.claim: Kerala legislature competent to give retrospectivity to validating law citing Mst. Jadao Bahuji precedent
arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguishable as Jadao validated pre-1939 excess under GOI Act s.142A, not post-commencement like here post-Constitution

arguments.claim: Amended proviso results in higher assessable profits due to fewer permissible deductions under Indian Income-tax Act compared to Travancore Act

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pai for the respondent contended that in consequence of the amendment the total profits earned by a company or person as disclosed by the income-tax statement for the whole of India will not have to be divided in the same proportion as the turnover of the business of the company or person within the municipality bore to the turn-over outside the municipality, or the purpose of assessment of the tax. The result of this, according to him, may sometimes be that a much larger amount of profits will have to be taken into account for assessing the tax than under the unamended proviso.

arguments.court_reasoning: Cannot deny possibility of fewer deductions under Indian I-T Act; introduces different statute for profits ascertainment

arguments.claim: Amendments to rules cannot have retrospective operation as power under s.325 does not permit it

anchor.surface_text: The validity of the amendments was challenged before the High Court in Highland Produce Co. Ltd. v. The Commissioner, Alleppey Municipal Council on the ground that the power conferred by S. 325 of the Act to frame rules could not be exercised so as to give retrospective operation to any rule.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court accepted contention; led to enactment of validating Act which is now struck down

arguments.claim: Proviso to r.18(2) rendered obsolete after Indian Income-tax Act due to inability to ascertain assessable area

anchor.surface_text: In Harrisons and Crosfield Ltd. v. Commissioner of Quilon Municipality the Travancore-Cochin High Court held that the proviso had only provided for the adoption of certain figures representing the total profits as disclosed by the Income-tax assessment for a particular year in which the emphasis was upon the assessable area, which, after the coming into force of the Indian Income-tax Act in the State of Travancore became impossible of ascertainment and that, therefore, the entire proviso was rendered obsolete.

arguments.claim: s.2 Validating Act violates Art.276 as it validates post-Constitution tax enhancement beyond Rs.250

anchor.surface_text: is whether s. 2 of the Kerala Profession Tax Validation and Reassessment Act, 1958 Act No. XIV of 1958 is invalid on the ground that it violates the provisions of Art. 276 of the Constitution.

arguments.court_reasoning: Validating post-1950 amendment enhancing tax violates Art.276 dateline proviso allowing only pre-Constitution excess continuation

holdings.text: The proviso affected the basis and incidence of the tax and did not merely provide a machinery for implementing the tax.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we cannot accept the contention of the learned Attorney-General that the proviso did not affect either the basis or the incidence of the tax but merely provided a machinery for implementing the tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso introduces new basis by linking taxable income to income-tax profits computation and apportionment by turnover, potentially higher due to deductions; separates income-tax assessees from others.

holdings.text: The amended proviso was likely to enhance an assessee's liability to profession tax.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, while dealing with the amendment made in the year 1956 we have to bear in mind that it was made in a provision concerning the basis of taxation. The question then would be whether the amended proviso was likely to enhance an assessee's liability.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendment substitutes Indian I-T Act (fewer deductions possible) for Travancore Act and 'whole State' to 'whole of India'; hypothetical figures (Ex.4,13,23) show higher TI2 than TI1 in some periods.

holdings.text: The decision in Mst. Jadao Bahuji is distinguishable as it concerned validation of pre-dateline excess, unlike here post-Constitution commencement.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Jadao validated pre-31 March 1939 excess under GOI Act s.142A; here validation for post-Constitution period exceeding Rs.250 violates Art.276 dateline proviso.

holdings.text: Section 2 of the Kerala Profession Tax Validation and Reassessment Act, 1958 (Act XIV of 1958) violates Article 276 and the Kerala Legislature was incompetent to enact it.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.276 proviso allows pre-Constitution excess taxes to continue but circumscribes power post-commencement; cannot retrospectively validate post-1950 amendment enhancing tax incidence beyond Rs.250.

precedents.citation: Harrisons and Crosfield Ltd. v. Commissioner of Quilon Municipality 1 I.L.R. 1955 T.C. 1003

anchor.surface_text: In Harrisons and Crosfield Ltd. v. Commissioner of Quilon Municipality 1  the Travancore-Cochin High Court held that the proviso had only provided for the adoption of certain figures representing the total profits as disclosed by the Income-tax assessment for a particular year in which the emphasis was upon the assessable area, which, after the coming into force of the Indian Income-tax Act in the State of Travancore became impossible of ascertainment and that, therefore, the entire proviso was rendered obsolete.

precedents.cited_holding: the entire proviso was rendered obsolete
